items.item_details:
The Board of Trustees offers an opportunity for the public to address the Board in four sections of the agenda: on matters of concern about Closed Session items; on matters not appearing on the agenda; on action items contained in the Consent Agenda; and prior to voting on any item contained in the Action Agenda. Each speaker is encouraged to submit a comment card to the Board clerk in order to be recognized to speak.
	Per Board Policy, three minutes may be allotted to each speaker with a maximum of 30 minutes per subject. No action or discussion shall be undertaken on any public comments except that members of the Board or its staff may briefly respond to or ask a question for clarification regarding statements made or questions posed by persons addressing the Board under this agenda item.
	For information and disability access to materials, call 408-288-3136. Meetings are held in a location accessible to the disabled.

items.item_details: For the past several years, Steve Hulse and the Purchasing Staff have hosted the SJECCD annual yard sale. The purpose of the yard sale is to provide an opportunity for employees, students, and the general public to purchase surplus material that is no longer of use by the District. Although much preparation is necessary for the success of this endeavor, the fiscal and environmental contributions make this a worthwhile task. The most recent yard sale took place on May 7 – 8, 2010, and resulted in over 27,000 lbs. of materials being diverted from landfill. The proceeds from the yard sale totaled over $9,700 that was contributed to the general fund. We would like to offer our thanks and recognition to Steve and the Purchasing Staff for their commitment to this worthwhile endeavor.
items.item_text: Recognition of Successful Annual Yard Sale

items.item_details:
The Workforce Institute is one of six entities named a recipient of the Green Innovation Challenge Grant award from the California Economic Development Department. The Institute has partnered with a host of organizations including PG & E, the California Building Performance Contractors Association, and the NUMMI Transition Center Network to identify and meet the short and long-term workforce needs of the Efficient Energy Home Building Performance market.  The innovative action plan will utilize a three-tiered training approach that will reduce barriers to the deployment of efficient energy practices and upcoming incentive programs. The plan will also provide pathways for sustained career advancement through a system of “stackable certificates” either through credit toward a degree or industry credentials. Cohort training programs include: Efficient Energy Outreach Specialist/Assessor; Building Information Modeling (BIM) for Efficient Energy; Home Performance w/ Energy Star; and Integrated Design Side Management for Power Engineers. The goal of the Institute’s Green Innovation Challenge grant award is to target the energy efficiency retrofit market and provide training programs within the 24-month grant timeline that: trains new professional workers who are essential to the job creation process, up-skill incumbent workers, and train former NUMMI employees and suppliers plus the region’s pool of unemployed/displaced workers. The term of this agreement is June 30, 2010 through June 30, 2012.
The contract with provide funding for a full-time Contracts Assistant and a 50% Project Supervisor over the 2-year grant term.
Funding will be distributed between the Workforce Institute and its subcontractors as outlined below:
            Workforce Institute                                                     $940,000
            California State University – East Bay                         $400,000
            ICF International                                                         $300,000
            Work2future                                                                $200,000
            Cal. Building Performance Contractors Assoc.                $80,000
            Modesto Junior College                                                  $40,000
            Chabot College                                                              $40,000
items.item_recommendation: It is recommended that the Board of Trustees approve the California Economic Development Department Green Innovation Challenge grant award.
items.item_text: Workforce Institute - Green Innovation Challenge Grant Award
items.item_text_raw: 11. Workforce Institute - Green Innovation Challenge Grant Award

items.item_details:
Since 2000, Workforce Institute has contracted with the City of San Jose to provide WIA intensive services and is being funded to continue those services for the 2010-11 program year.Â  Services include eligibility determination, assessment, counseling/case management, job development/placement services, for Adults and Dislocated Workers that are 18 or older that have been affected by the downturn in the economy. Program services are also delivered to employers in Santa Clara County. These services include placement assistance, job fair participation, career coaching and Career Readiness Certificate test proctoring. These services are provided at the San Jose One Stop, the Campbell One Stop and the Gilroy One Stop.
The Center for Training and Careers will be subcontracted to provided specialized services to the participants at the Gilroy One Stop. They will receive $81,720 to provide these services.
items.item_recommendation: It is recommended that the Board of Trustees approve the WIA Work2future Adult Case Management Contract.
items.item_text: Workforce Institute - WIA Work2future Adult Case Management Contract
items.item_text_raw: 12. Workforce Institute - WIA Work2future Adult Case Management Contract

items.item_details: Since 2005, Workforce Institute has contracted with the City of San Jose to provide WIA Youth intensive services and is being funded to continue those services for the 2010-11 program year.  Services include eligibility determination, assessment, counseling/case management, job development/placement services, for youth ages 17-21 who are low income with at least one barrier to obtaining employment. This program offers the WorkKeys Career Readiness Certificate, National Retail Federation's Customer Service Training and a choice of enrollment into the San Jose Promise Program, Pathways to Teaching, Water Utilities Training or PG&E's Energy Auditor Specialist Training. Upon completion of training, participants receive one-on-one job placement assistance. Incentives and supportive services are offered throughout the program to ensure that the participants finish the program.
items.item_recommendation: It is recommended that the Board of Trustees approve the WIA Work2future Youth Case Management Contract.
items.item_text: Workforce Institute— WIA Work2future Youth Case Management Contract
items.item_text_raw: 13. Workforce Institute— WIA Work2future Youth Case Management Contract

items.item_details:
Since 2000 Workforce Institute has contracted with the City of San Jose (work2future) to provide a wide variety of job readiness workshops to Santa Clara County job seekers.   Since 2005 Workforce Institute has delivered over 15,000 hours of job readiness (225,000 attendees) workshops at multiple locations including the three primary work2future One-Stops (Campbell, Gilroy and San Jose).  Since 2008 Workforce Institute has provided online training to over 1,000 job seekers in an effort to equip them with the skills (high level programming, project management, accounting, entrepreneurship, etc.) they need to market themselves in this tight economic market.
 
For program year 2010-2011, work2future has awarded Workforce Institute $1,208,920 for continuing services.
 
In an effort to meet the diverse needs of Santa Clara County job seekers, Workforce Institute is subcontracting with the following entities:
 
1. Center for Training and Careers (CTC) -- Job Readiness Workshops ($152,320) 
2. Gavilan College -- English/Spanish Job Readiness Workshops at the Gilroy One-Stop ($24,640)
3. Career Advancement Solutions (CAS) -- Job Readiness Workshops ($54,080)
items.item_recommendation: It is recommended that the Board of Trustees approve the 2010-2011 WIA Workshop Contract.
items.item_text: Workforce Institute - WIA Work2future Workshop Contract
items.item_text_raw: 14. Workforce Institute - WIA Work2future Workshop Contract

items.item_details:
Evergreen Valley College conducted a self study for submission to the Western Association of Schools and Colleges (WASC), Accrediting Commission for Community and Junior Colleges (AACJC).  Faculty, staff, students and administrators from across campus participated in the self study.  It was a very diverse, qualified, and motivated group of leaders who brought a rnage of experience and perspectives to this process. 
	 
The report has been reviewed by and accepted by all governance groups on campus.  This final Accreditation Self Study document will be sent to AACJC in July.  The AACJC site visit is scheduled for October 18-21, 2010.
items.item_recommendation: A recommendation that the Board of Trustees approve the submission of Evergreen Valley College's 2010 Accreditation Self Study to WASC, AACJC.
items.item_text: B-2010 Accreditatioin Self Study - Evergreen Valley College
items.item_text_raw: 17. B-2010 Accreditatioin Self Study - Evergreen Valley College

items.item_details:
A recommendation that the Board of Trustees review the draft of the San Jose City College Accreditation Self Study for 2009-2010 to WASC, AACJC. The Board of Trustees may review the draft through July 20, 2010 and submit recommendation to the accreditation chair, Celia Cruz-Johnson, celia.cruz@sjcc.edu. 
 
San Jose City College conducted a self study for submission to the Western Association of Schools and Colleges (WASC), Accrediting Commission for Community and Junior Colleges (ACCJC).   In an open process, faculty, staff, students, and administrators have had the opportunity to participate in the accreditation process.  
 
A draft of the self study report has been reviewed by and accepted by all governance groups on campus.  The final Accreditation Self Study document will be sent to AACJC no later mid August. The AACJC site visit is scheduled for October 18 to 21 of 2010.
items.item_recommendation: A recommendation that the Board of Trustees approve the submission of San Jose City College's Accreditation Self Study for 09-10 to WASC, ACCJC

items.item_details:
Education Code 81655 stipulates that no contract is an enforceable obligation of the district until it has been approved by the Board of Trustees. District policy adopted on April 10, 2007 establishes the authority of certain administrators to approve contracts under the bid limit prior to formal Board approval.Â  All contracts and purchase orders exceeding the bid limit (currently $78,500) should have prior board approval as a separate Board item.
This consent item presents for Board approval:Â  all purchase orders for this period which includes all purchase orders for administratively-approved contracts exceeding $750 as well as any additional contracts that are not executed by way of purchase order as deemed appropriate to be added by purchasing.

items.item_details:
The initial process for completing the SEIR for the San Jose City College Educational and Facilities Master Plan Update - 2011 has been modified and extended due to the action in November 2008 by the District Board of Trustees who determined the proposed Educational and Facilities Master Plan Update - 2011 required extensive modification and directed District staff and the consultants to file a modified SEIR (Subsequent Environmental Impact Report) for the San Jose City College Facilities Master Plan Update 2011.
	 
The Board of Trustees determined it was in the best interest of the District to continue master planning activities for the district by preparing additional master planning documents through the year 2025, entitled "Educational and Facilities Master Plan Update - 2025" for each college and the District.  An additional SEIR process will follow for the Districtwide Facilities Master Plan Update 2025 upon its completion in the fall 2010.
items.item_recommendation: A recommendation that the Board if Trustees approve a Consultant Services Agreement with Maas Companies, Inc. in the amount of not to exceed $130,000.00, to provide comprehensive consulting services for the completion of the Subsequent Environmental Impact Report for the 2011 Update of the Educational and Facilities Master Plans for San Jose City College.

items.item_details:
Under the California Environmental Quality Act (“CEQA”), the Final Subsequent Environmental Impact Report (“FSEIR”) cannot be used to approve the Facilities Master Plan Update 2011 (“Update”) or individual buildings described in the Update unless it is certified.  Certification is a procedure under CEQA where the Board of Trustees adopts findings related to the factual conclusions and analysis of environmental impacts of the FSEIR.  In addition, by adopting the findings the Board of Trustees is also stating that it is their judgment that the FSEIR is adequate and accurate under CEQA.  
	 
 
The sole purpose of certification is for the Trustees to decide whether the FSEIR satisfies CEQA.  That includes whether the Trustees decision to certify the FSEIR is based on their review of the Revised Draft SEIR, and the record prepared in support of the FSEIR, including comments and responses to those comments.  The Findings for the Update serve six (6) purposes:
1.         Describe the Update, the environmental review process for it, and the location of records.
2.         Describe the impacts of the Update;
3.         Evaluate alternatives to the Update and the economic, legal, social, technological, and other considerations that support the rejection of the alternatives; 
4.         Identify potentially significant impacts that are avoided or reduced to less-than-significant levels and makes findings regarding mitigation measures that eliminate or reduce the significance;
5.         Determines that there are significant unavoidable impacts to traffic resources that cannot be avoided or reduced to less-than-significant levels through Mitigation Measures.
6.         Due to the existence of unavoidable significant impacts, adopts a statement of overriding considerations such that the economic, legal, social, technological, or other benefits of the Update outweigh the unavoidable adverse environmental effects.  
 
CEQA does not require there be a public hearing on certification.  Public review of the SEIR has occurred during the public comment period.  Because there is no hearing on this item, public comment on the certification will occur during the public comment period on this Agenda.  
	 
The FSEIR is accessible via the following link.
	 
http://www.maasco.com/clients/sje.asp
items.item_recommendation: A recommendation that the Board of Trustees adopt the resolution certifying the Final Subsequent Environmental Impact Report for the San Jose City College Facilities Master Plan Update 2011.

items.item_text_raw: 1. Certification of the Final Supplemental Environmental Impact Report-2011 Facilities Master Plan Update-San Jose City College

items.item_details:
The Facilities Master Plan Update 2011 (“2011 Update”) was prepared to address physical changes to the San Jose City College Campus (“College”) that have occurred since the adoption of the Facilities Master Plan Update in 2000.  The Final Subsequent Environmental Impact Report for the 2011 Update (“FSEIR”) was prepared in compliance with the California Environmental Quality Act (“CEQA”) for the approval of the Update by the Trustees.  Without a certified FSEIR, the Update could not lawfully be approved and implemented by the Trustees.  
	 
The FSEIR described those physical changes to the College that have occurred since 2000 and proposed additional physical changes to the College that will occur by the end of 2010 with implementation of the Update.  This includes buildings and facilities that will be demolished and constructed.  In addition, the FSEIR evaluated whether there may be environmental impacts from those changes that will occur by the end of 2010, and if so, whether those impacts could be reduced or avoided by adopting mitigation measures as part of implementation of the Update.  
	 
Approval of the Update is within the Trustees’ discretion.  The Trustees can determine, based on their review of the Update and the FSEIR and their consideration of staff presentations, public testimony and other factors reasonably related to the purpose of the Update, whether the Update should be approved and if so, what conditions should be imposed.  The Trustees' decision to approve the Update will be memorialized in a Resolution of Project Approval.  That Resolution will include findings that, among other things, the Trustees have reviewed and considered the FSEIR, its analysis of impacts, evaluation of mitigation measures and rejection of alternatives.    
	 
Because the FSEIR determined that the Update would have significant impacts that can be reduced or eliminated through the imposition of mitigation measures, the Findings will include the mitigation measures to be adopted by the Trustees as conditions of approval of the Update, as set forth in the Mitigation Monitoring and Reporting Program, which is incorporated into the Findings.  Additionally, the FSEIR found that there will be impacts to the intersection of Bascom and Kingman Avenues that cannot be eliminated or reduced to less than significant levels by the Trustees due to the fact that Santa Clara County, and not the Trustees, owns the intersection.  Due to this, the Trustees must also adopt a Statement of Overriding Considerations for their approval of the Update, describing how the Update’s unavoidable impact to the traffic at the intersection of Bascom and Kingman Avenues is outweighed by the benefits to the College from implementation of the Update.
  
	Once the 2011 Facilities Master Plan Update is approved by the Trustees, College staff is free to take specific actions necessary to implement the Update, including, but not limited to, executing contracts and appropriating monies.
items.item_recommendation: A recommendation that the Board of Trustees adopt the resolution approving the 2011 San Jose City College Facilities Master Plan Update.
items.item_text: Adoption of Resolution to Approve the SJCC 2011 Facilities Master Plan Update, including findings based on the Final Subsequent Environmental Impact Report prepared for the update.
items.item_text_raw: 2. Adoption of Resolution to Approve the SJCC 2011 Facilities Master Plan Update, including findings based on the Final Subsequent Environmental Impact Report prepared for the update.

items.item_details:
The San José Evergreen Community College District has historically supported policies that prohibit discrimination based upon an individual’s race, ethnicity, national origin, or other legally protected status.  Our District’s core values are opportunity, equity and social justice.  Each one of these values is incorporated into our strategic planning and is a part of the foundational commitments we make to our communities as we use the tool of higher education to bring them to life.    
Arizona Senate Bill SB 1070 is a law that seeks to implement Arizona’s own scheme of immigration regulation and will inevitably lead to racial profiling of people of color and limited English proficient persons.
items.item_recommendation: A recommendation that the Board of Trustees call for a boycott of the State of Arizona and Arizona based businesses until Arizona repeals Senate Bill 1070.
items.item_text: Resolution to Boycott Arizona Senate Bill 1070
items.item_text_raw: 4. Resolution to Boycott Arizona Senate Bill 1070

items.item_details:
San Jose/Evergreen Community College District (SJECCD) has maintained a long-term relationship with the Eastside Union High School District (ESUHSD).  Faced with issues of overcrowding, ESUHSD began leasing facilities from SJECCD in 2004, which was viewed as a way to further link our colleges to one of SJECCD’s major feeder school districts.  ESUHSD currently occupies ten (10) portable classrooms located near the Cedro Building at Evergreen Valley College.  The lease allows SJECCD to recover direct costs related to the use of the facilities.
	 
The Resolution, which must be unanimously approved, gives authorization for the Vice Chancellor of Administrative Services to execute the lease following public notice.
items.item_recommendation: It is recommended that the Board of Trustees approve the Resolution authorizing a lease between San Jose/Evergreen Community College District and Eastside Union High School District.
items.item_text: Resolution - Facilities Lease with Eastside Union High School District
items.item_text_raw: 7. Resolution - Facilities Lease with Eastside Union High School District

items.item_details:
The Board of Trustees gave direction on June 9, 2009 to "identify an appropriate community partner to provide child care for students, faculty, staff and the public at EVC."  Notice to lease was provided as an Information item at the August 11, 2009 meeting.  Public Notice has been provided in the San Jose Mercury News once per week for a period of three weeks as required by Ed Code Sec. 81378.
 
A lessee has been identified and the District is ready to proceed with execution of a lease with Empire Montessori Preschool.  The Vice Chancellor of Administrative Services will negotiate the final terms and conditions of the lease exclusive of the lease value as approved by the Board of Trustees.
 
Comparable listings in the area were identified to determine a lease amount excluding common area maintenance, utilities and insurance.  Based on comparable lease space listed at rofo.com, a commercial real estate site, the current market rate for a similar property is $0.75 to $0.85 per square foot.  However, the EVC Child Development Center does have considerable wear and tear; therefore a fair market value of $0.69 per square foot has been recommended.  In addition, the lessee will cover actual costs associated with common area maintenance, utilities, and insurance.  The EVC Child Development Center is a total of 2,996 square feet.
 
All revenue derived pursuant to this lease will be retained for exclusive use by the District and will not exceed $25,000 per year, as certified by the Board of Trustees.
items.item_recommendation: It is recommended that the Board of Trustees approve leasing the Evergreen Valley College Child Development Center to Empire Montessori School for an amount not to exceed $25,000 as per Ed Code Sec. 81378.
items.item_text: Lease for Child Development Center - EVC
items.item_text_raw: 8. Lease for Child Development Center - EVC

items.item_details:
Pursuant to Government Code Section 3547, the San Jose/Evergreen Community College District and the Faculty Association, AFT 6157, present their Collective bargaining agreement negotiation proposals for the 2010-2011 fiscal year. The Union and District will be proposing to roll over the full contract until June 30, 2011 as follows:
Article 8, Full-Time faculty Salary
The parties mutually agree to open this Article in 2010-11 negotiations if it is necessary to close the 2010/2011 budget gap to reach a 5% ending fund balance reserve with contributions of salary savings by theUnion. The salary savings are to be realized in fiscal year 2010-2011. If it is necessary to reopen Article 8, using the a la carte menu as a guide, negotiations will proceed on this Article. This article would only be reopened after the District closes its books and the state and the District have adopted 2010-2011 budgets.
Article 17, Benefits
The parties mutually agree to open this Article in 2010-11 negotiations to have the District cover the increased cost of all health and welfare benefits through June 30, 2011.
Article 18, Retirement
The parties mutually agree to open this Article in 2010-11 negotiations to have the District cover the increased cost of all health and welfare benefits for retirees through June 30, 2011.
Article 32, Term
The parties mutually agree to open this Article in 2010-11 negotiations to extend the terms and conditions of the 2009-2010 contract until June 30, 2011.
New articles mutually agreed upon by the parties arising after the presentation of initial proposals shall be made public within 24 hours and the Board shall take action at a public meeting.
RECOMMENDATION:
Government Code 3547 requires that all initial proposals of exclusive representatives and of public school employees which relates to matters within the scope of representation shall be presented at a public meeting of the public school employer and thereafter shall become public record.Â  It is recommended that the Board conduct a public hearing at the August 10, 2010 Board meeting to allow the public the opportunity to express itself regarding the proposals and at the end of the public hearing adopt the proposals.
